RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN





FOR:    ANHYDROUS AMMONIA HANDLING





VERTELLUS LLC

MANUFACTURING FACILITY

DELAWARE WATER GAP, PA



IN COMPLIANCE WITH 40 CFR 68



Kevinn P. Kramer

VERTELLUS LLC

 



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The facility policy is to adhere, at a minimum, to the applicable Federal and state rules and regulations that govern accidental release prevention and emergency response. The facility has policies and programs for accidental releases and spills and emergency response.



The facility conforms to and has been certified to RCMS 2008; Environmental, Health, Safety and Security Management System.  RCMS stands for Responsible Care Management System offers an integrated, structured approach to improve company performance in the following key areas: community awareness and emergency response; security; distribution; employee health and safety; pollution prevention; and process and product safety. 

 

The facility handles anhydrous ammonia to produce ammonia salts and may store up to 52,000 lbs. of anhydrous ammonia.



Ammonia is stored in tank that has a maximum volume of 12,000 gal. Unloading procedures require operators to fill to no greater than 80% of capacity or 9600 gallons.  Based on a density of 5.4 lb/gal at 20?F, that corresponds to a weight of 51,840 lb (~52,000 lb) 23,600 kg when converted to kilograms and rounded up to the nearest 100 kg.



Management places a strong emphasis on worker safety and accident prevention.  Conscientious efforts by trained personnel ensure that the facility operates within the guidelines established by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) and its Process Safety Management Program.  Training and experience prepares them to manage operations on a 24-hour a day, 7-day a week schedule.   



The facility has not had any reportable accidents from covered processes in the past 5-years.  



An emergency response plan for the facility has been prepared and provided to emergency responders, including Mo

nroe County LEPC (local emergency planning committee), local Fire companies, and the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Resources.  The facility was recognized in 1996 by the USEPA (United States Environmental Protection Agency) with the presentation of the Partnership Award.  The award recognizes extraordinary contributions to chemical emergency preparedness and prevention programs.
